jsx.dom
Class Elements

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      jsx.dom.Elements

public final class Elements
extends Disposable

A utility class manipulating DOM elements with its static methods.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org

Method Detail

createElement

public static final JsElement createElement(java.lang.String tagName)

Creates a new JsElement node with the specified tag name.

Parameters:
tagName - The tag name of the JsElement node being created. Since HTML tags are case-insensitive, you may use any capitalization for HTML tag names. XML tag names are case-sensitive.
Returns:
A newly created JsElement node with the specified tag name.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR if tagName contains an illegal character. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Document.createElement(String), JsDocument.createElement(String)

createElementNS

public static final JsElement createElementNS(java.lang.String namespaceURI,
                                              java.lang.String qualifiedName)

Creates a new JsElement node with the specified tag name and name-space.

This method is just like createElement(String), except that the created JsElement node has a name and name space instead of just a name. This method is useful only with XML documents that use name spaces.

Parameters:
namespaceURI - The unique identifier for the name space of the new JsElement node or null for no name space.
qualifiedName - The qualified name of the new JsElement node. This should include a name space prefix, a colon, and a local name.
Returns:
A newly created JsElement node with the specified tag name and name space.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR if qualifiedName contains an illegal character, the value JsDOMException.NAMESPACE_ERR if qualifiedName is malformed or there is a mismatch between qualifiedName and namespaceURI, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR if the implementation does not support XML documents and therefore does not implement this method. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsDocument.createElementNS(String, String)

getAttribute

public static final java.lang.String getAttribute(JsElement e,
                                                  java.lang.String name)

Returns the value of a named attribute as a string.

This method returns the value of a named attribute of an element. Note that the JsHTMLElement objects have JavaScript properties that match each of the standard HTML attributes, so you need to use this method with HTML documents only if you are querying the value of nonstandard attributes.

In XML documents, attribute values are not available directly as element properties and must be looked up by calling this method. For XML documents that use name spaces, use getAttributeNS(JsElement, String, String).

Parameters:
e - The current element.
name - The name of the attribute whose value is to be returned.
Returns:
The value of the named attribute as a string. If the attribute is not defined, this method is supposed to return an empty string. Some implementations return null in this case, however.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.getAttribute(String)

getAttributeNS

public static final java.lang.String getAttributeNS(JsElement e,
                                                    java.lang.String namespaceURI,
                                                    java.lang.String localName)

Returns the string value of an attribute specified by local name and name space URI.

This method is useful only with XML documents that use name spaces and works just like the getAttribute(JsElement, String) method, except that the attribute is specified by a combination of name space URI and local name within that name space.

Parameters:
e - The current element.
namespaceURI - The URI that uniquely identifies the name space of this attribute or null for no name space.
localName - The identifier that specifies the name of the attribute within its name space.
Returns:
The value of the named attribute, as a string. If the attribute is not defined, this method is supposed to return an empty string, but some implementations return null instead.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.getAttributeNodeNS(String, String)

setAttribute

public static final void setAttribute(JsElement e,
                                      java.lang.String name,
                                      java.lang.Object value)

Sets or adds the named attribute to the specified string value.

This method sets the specified attribute to the specified value. If no attribute by that name already exists, a new one is created.

Note that JsHTMLElement objects of an HTML document define JavaScript properties that correspond to all standard HTML attributes. Thus, you need to use this method only if you want to set a nonstandard attribute.

Parameters:
e - The current element.
name - The name of the attribute to be created or modified.
value - The string value of the attribute.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this element is read-only and does not allow its attributes to be removed or the value JsDOMException.INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR if the name argument contains a character that is not allowed in HTML or XML attribute names. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.setAttribute(String, Object)

setAttributeNS

public static final void setAttributeNS(JsElement e,
                                        java.lang.String namespaceURI,
                                        java.lang.String localName,
                                        java.lang.String value)

Sets or adds, to the list of attributes for this element, an attribute with the specified a combination of local name and name space URI.

This method is useful only with XML documents that use name spaces and works just like setAttribute(JsElement, String, Object) method, except that the attribute is specified by the combination of a name space URI and a local name defined within that name space.

Parameters:
e - The current element.
namespaceURI - The URI that uniquely identifies the name space of the attribute to be set or created, or null for no name space.
localName - The name of the attribute, specified as an optional name space prefix and colon followed by the local name within the name space.
value - The new value of the attribute.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this element is read-only and does not allow its attributes to be removed, the value JsDOMException.INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR if qualifiedName argument contains a character that is not allowed in HTML or XML attribute names, the value JsDOMException.NAMESPACE_ERR if qualifiedName is malformed, or there is a mismatch between the name space prefix of qualifiedName and the namespaceURI argument, or the value JsDOMException.NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR if the DOM implementation of the browser does not support XML documents. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.setAttributeNS(String, String, String)

removeAttribute

public static final void removeAttribute(JsElement e,
                                         java.lang.String name)

Removes the named attribute from this element.

This method deletes a named attribute from this element. If the named attribute has a default value specified by the document type, subsequent calls to this method return that default value. Attempts to remove nonexistent attributes or attributes that are not specified but have a default value are silently ignored.

Parameters:
e - The current element.
name - The name of the desired attribute.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this element is read-only and does not allow its attributes to be removed. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.removeAttribute(String)

removeAttributeNS

public static final void removeAttributeNS(JsElement e,
                                           java.lang.String namespaceURI,
                                           java.lang.String localName)

Removes, from this element, an attribute with the specified a combination of local name and name space URI.

This method is useful only with XML documents that use name spaces and works just like removeAttribute(JsElement, String) method, except that the attribute to be removed is specified by the combination of a name space URI and a local name defined within that name space.

Parameters:
e - The current element.
namespaceURI - The URI that uniquely identifies the name space of this attribute or null for no name space.
localName - The identifier that specifies the name of the attribute within its name space.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a JsDOMException object with the JsDOMException.code property of the value JsDOMException.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this element is read-only and does not allow its attributes to be removed. See Js.err(Object) for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.removeAttributeNS(String, String)

isHTMLElement

public static final boolean isHTMLElement(JsElement e)

Determines if a given element is an HTML element.

This method does the job by only testing the existence of JsHTMLElement.style property in the element object.

Parameters:
e - The given element.
Returns:
true if it is an HTML element; false, otherwise.
Since:
1.0

currentStyle

public static final JsObject currentStyle(JsHTMLElement e)

Gets or computes the JsHTMLElement.currentStyle of an HTML element.

This method eliminates the browser dependencies.

Parameters:
e - The given HTML element.
Returns:
The current JsCSS2Properties object in the element.
Since:
1.0
